Center Manifold for PDE Dynamics: A Concrete Example

Dynamical Systems Center Manifold PDE
Updated on Nov 30, 2025

Consider the 111-dimensional parabolic problem

ut=uxx+(μ+1)u−u2,u(x,t)∈Hper1(0,2π)×R≥0.\begin{align*} &u_t = u_{xx} + (\mu+1)u - u^2,\\ &u(x,t) \in H^1_{\text{per}}(0,2\pi)\times \mathbb{R}_{\geq0}. \end{align*}​ut​=uxx​+(μ+1)u−u2,u(x,t)∈Hper1​(0,2π)×R≥0​.​

We study the local dynamics near the trivial solution u=μ=0u=\mu=0u=μ=0.

Linear Analysis

Write the equation as

ut=Lu+N(u;μ),u_t = L u+N(u;\mu),ut​=Lu+N(u;μ),

where L=∂xx+1L = \partial_{xx} + 1L=∂xx​+1 and N(u;μ)=μu−u2N(u;\mu) = \mu u - u^2N(u;μ)=μu−u2. We can find the eigenvalues through the linearization at (u,μ)=(0,0)(u,\mu) = (0,0)(u,μ)=(0,0),

Leikx=λkeikx,L e^{ikx} = \lambda_k e^{ikx},Leikx=λk​eikx,

yielding the eigenvalues: λk=1−k2,k∈Z\lambda_k = 1 - k^2, k\in \mathbb{Z}λk​=1−k2,k∈Z.

Center Subspace (EcE^cEc) The center subspace corresponds to eigenvalues with zero real part (λk=0\lambda_k = 0λk​=0).

1−k2=0  ⟹  k=±1.1 - k^2 = 0 \implies k = \pm 1.1−k2=0⟹k=±1.

Thus, the center subspace is spanned by the modes eixe^{ix}eix and e−ixe^{-ix}e−ix.

Ec=span{eix,e−ix}.E^c = \text{span}\{ e^{ix}, e^{-ix} \}.Ec=span{eix,e−ix}.

Hyperbolic Subspace (EhE^hEh) The hyperbolic subspace corresponds to eigenvalues with non-zero real parts (k≠±1k \neq \pm 1k=±1). Therefore, the hyperbolic subspace is spanned by all the other modes.

Eh=span{eikx∣k∈Z,k≠±1}.E^h = \text{span}\{ e^{ikx} \mid k \in \mathbb{Z}, k \neq \pm 1 \}.Eh=span{eikx∣k∈Z,k=±1}.

1. Projections

We define the projection operators PcP_cPc​ and PhP_hPh​ onto the center and hyperbolic subspaces, respectively:

The projection operator PcP_cPc​ onto the center subspace EcE^cEc for a function u(x)u(x)u(x), using the standard L2L^2L2 inner product ⟨f,g⟩=12π∫02πf(x)gˉ(x)dx\langle f, g \rangle = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f(x) \bar{g}(x) dx⟨f,g⟩=2π1​∫02π​f(x)gˉ​(x)dx, is given by

Pcu=⟨u,eix⟩eix+⟨u,e−ix⟩e−ixP_c u = \langle u, e^{ix} \rangle e^{ix} + \langle u, e^{-ix} \rangle e^{-ix}Pc​u=⟨u,eix⟩eix+⟨u,e−ix⟩e−ix

The projection onto the hyperbolic subspace is the complement: Phu=(I−Pc)uP_h u = (I - P_c) uPh​u=(I−Pc​)u

For convenience, we use the projection acting on the Fourier series of a function f(x)=∑fkeikxf(x) = \sum f_k e^{ikx}f(x)=∑fk​eikx throughout this article.

Projection onto Center Subspace (PcP_cPc​)

Pcf:=f1eix+f−1e−ixP_c f := f_1 e^{ix} + f_{-1} e^{-ix}Pc​f:=f1​eix+f−1​e−ix

Projection onto Hyperbolic Subspace (PhP_hPh​)

Phf:=f−Pcf=∑k≠±1fkeikxP_h f := f - P_c f = \sum_{k \neq \pm 1} f_k e^{ikx}Ph​f:=f−Pc​f=k=±1∑​fk​eikx

2. Substitute the Ansatz

We decompose the solution uuu onto components on the center and hyperbolic subspaces:

u(x,t)=v(x,t)+w(x,t)u(x,t) = v(x,t) + w(x,t)u(x,t)=v(x,t)+w(x,t)

where v∈Ecv \in E^cv∈Ec and w∈Ehw \in E^hw∈Eh, and then substitute it into the PDE:

vt+wt=L(v+w)+μ(v+w)−(v+w)2=Lw+μv+μw−(v2+2vw+w2)\begin{align*} v_t + w_t &= L(v+w) + \mu(v+w) - (v+w)^2\\ &= L w + \mu v + \mu w - (v^2 + 2vw + w^2) \end{align*}vt​+wt​​=L(v+w)+μ(v+w)−(v+w)2=Lw+μv+μw−(v2+2vw+w2)​

because Lv=0L v =0Lv=0. Here, vvv and www can be expressed using the amplitude A(t)A(t)A(t) and the bases of the center and hyperbolic subspaces:

v(x,t)=A(t)eix+Aˉ(t)e−ix,w(x,t)=∑k≠±1wk(A(t),Aˉ(t),μ)eikx\begin{align*} v(x,t) &= A(t)e^{ix} + \bar{A}(t)e^{-ix},\\ w(x,t) &= \sum_{k \neq \pm 1} w_k(A(t),\bar A(t),\mu) e^{ikx} \end{align*}v(x,t)w(x,t)​=A(t)eix+Aˉ(t)e−ix,=k=±1∑​wk​(A(t),Aˉ(t),μ)eikx​

We project this equation onto EcE^cEc and EhE^hEh.

Projection onto EcE^cEc:

vt=Pc[μv−v2−2vw−w2]v_t = P_c [\mu v - v^2 - 2vw - w^2]vt​=Pc​[μv−v2−2vw−w2]

because the ttt-derivative does not change the modes of www on the LHS (so Lwt=0L w_t = 0Lwt​=0), and Pc(Lw)=L(Pcw)=0P_c(Lw) = L(P_c w) = 0Pc​(Lw)=L(Pc​w)=0, Pc(μw)=0P_c (\mu w) = 0Pc​(μw)=0 on the RHS. Extracting the coefficient of eixe^{ix}eix gives the reduced equation with respect to AAA:

A˙=μA−⟨v2+2vw+w2,eix⟩\dot{A} = \mu A - \langle v^2 + 2vw + w^2, e^{ix} \rangleA˙=μA−⟨v2+2vw+w2,eix⟩

Note: This projection produces another reduced equation that involves Aˉ˙\dot{\bar{A}}Aˉ˙ by collecting the e−ixe^{-ix}e−ix terms. We are omitting it because it is simply a conjugate copy of the A˙\dot{A}A˙ equation. In general, a center subspace spanned by two generic basis functions would result in a 222-dimensional reduced system.

Projection onto EhE^hEh:

wt=Lw+Ph[μv+μw−v2−2vw−w2]w_t = L w + P_h [\mu v + \mu w - v^2 - 2vw - w^2]wt​=Lw+Ph​[μv+μw−v2−2vw−w2]

Since Ph(μv)=0P_h(\mu v) = 0Ph​(μv)=0 (because v∈Ecv \in E^cv∈Ec), this simplifies to:

wt=Lw+μw−Ph[v2+2vw+w2]w_t = L w + \mu w - P_h [v^2 + 2vw + w^2]wt​=Lw+μw−Ph​[v2+2vw+w2]

To summarize, we have now computed the reduced equation on EcE^cEc up to the first order

A˙=μA+O(∣A∣2).\dot{A} = \mu A + O(|A|^2).A˙=μA+O(∣A∣2).

Higher Orders

To close the reduced equation at cubic order O(∣A∣3)O(|A|^3)O(∣A∣3), we need www at quadratic order O(∣A∣2)O(|A|^2)O(∣A∣2). Thus, we can neglect the 2vw2vw2vw and w2w^2w2 terms in the www-equation as they are of order 333 and 444, respectively. Recall that the reduced EhE^hEh equation for www is:

wt−Lw−μw=−Ph(v2)w_t - L w - \mu w = -P_h(v^2)wt​−Lw−μw=−Ph​(v2)

We expand www in the hyperbolic modes:

w(x)=w0(μ,A,Aˉ)+w2(μ,A,Aˉ)e2ix+w−2(μ,A,Aˉ)e−2ix+…w(x) = w_0(\mu, A, \bar{A}) + w_2(\mu, A, \bar{A})e^{2ix} + w_{-2}(\mu, A, \bar{A})e^{-2ix} + \dotsw(x)=w0​(μ,A,Aˉ)+w2​(μ,A,Aˉ)e2ix+w−2​(μ,A,Aˉ)e−2ix+…

Now compute each term of the reduced EhE^hEh equation.

RHS term Pc(v2)P_c(v^2)Pc​(v2):

v2=(Aeix+Aˉe−ix)2=A2e2ix+2AAˉ+Aˉ2e−2ixv^2 = (Ae^{ix} + \bar{A}e^{-ix})^2 = A^2 e^{2ix} + 2A\bar{A} + \bar{A}^2 e^{-2ix}v2=(Aeix+Aˉe−ix)2=A2e2ix+2AAˉ+Aˉ2e−2ix

All terms of v2v^2v2 are in EhE^hEh (modes 0 and ±2\pm 2±2). So Pc(v2)=v2P_c(v^2) = v^2Pc​(v2)=v2.

LHS term wtw_twt​: Using the chain rule and the fact that www depends on time only through AAA and Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ:

wt=∂w∂AA˙+∂w∂AˉAˉ˙w_t = \frac{\partial w}{\partial A}\dot{A} + \frac{\partial w}{\partial \bar{A}}\dot{\bar{A}}wt​=∂A∂w​A˙+∂Aˉ∂w​Aˉ˙

At leading order, A˙≈μA\dot{A} \approx \mu AA˙≈μA. (we only need the linear term from the previous section here because www is already second order; higher order corrections to A˙\dot{A}A˙ would push the result to O(∣A∣4)O(|A|^4)O(∣A∣4)). Thus,

wt≈μA∂w∂A+μAˉ∂w∂Aˉw_t \approx \mu A \frac{\partial w}{\partial A} + \mu \bar{A} \frac{\partial w}{\partial \bar{A}}wt​≈μA∂A∂w​+μAˉ∂Aˉ∂w​

To be very, very precise, we can assume that wkw_kwk​ take the form

wk(μ,A,Aˉ)=∑α,β,γ∈Zwk,α,β,γμαAβAˉγw_k(\mu, A,\bar A) = \sum_{\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{Z}} w_{k,\alpha,\beta,\gamma} \mu^\alpha A^\beta \bar{A}^\gammawk​(μ,A,Aˉ)=α,β,γ∈Z∑​wk,α,β,γ​μαAβAˉγ

in which case the derivatives ∂w∂A\frac{\partial w}{\partial A}∂A∂w​ and ∂w∂Aˉ\frac{\partial w}{\partial \bar{A}}∂Aˉ∂w​ becomes explicit. The radius of convergence of this power series is not a concern as the center manifold only makes sense locally.

3: More Substitution and Projections

Assume w0=C0AAˉw_0=C_0 A \bar Aw0​=C0​AAˉ, w−2=C−2Aˉ2w_{-2}=C_{-2}\bar A^2w−2​=C−2​Aˉ2, and w2=C2A2w_2 = C_2 A^2w2​=C2​A2 for some C0,±2(μ)C_{0,\pm 2}(\mu)C0,±2​(μ). How do I know that these are all the terms for each wkw_kwk​? In other words, what happens if we include another term in one of the wkw_kwk​‘s, say, w0=C0AAˉ+C0∗A2w_0 = C_0 A \bar A + C_0^* A^2w0​=C0​AAˉ+C0∗​A2? In this case, the e0ixe^{0ix}e0ix (constant) terms of the equation becomes

C0(A˙Aˉ+AAˉ˙)+2C0∗AA˙⏟Substitite A˙≈μA−(1+μ)(C0AAˉ+C0∗A2⏟The only A2 term)=2AAˉ\underbrace{C_0(\dot{A}\bar{A}+A\dot{\bar{A}}) + 2C_0^* A \dot{A}}_{\text{Substitite }\dot{A}\approx \mu A} - (1+\mu)(C_0 A \bar A + \underbrace{C_0^* A^2}_{\text{The only } A^2 \text{ term}}) = 2A\bar{A}Substitite A˙≈μAC0​(A˙Aˉ+AAˉ˙)+2C0∗​AA˙​​−(1+μ)(C0​AAˉ+The only A2 termC0∗​A2​​)=2AAˉ

Note that this is the only equation that involves C0C_0C0​ and C0∗C_0^*C0∗​ because the linear operator (∂t−L−μ)(\partial_t - L - \mu)(∂t​−L−μ) on the LHS does not change the mode of the input function. The constant term on the RHS only has an AAˉA \bar AAAˉ term in its coefficient and hence forces C0∗=0C_0^*=0C0∗​=0. This observation enables us to eliminate most of the terms with zero coefficients.

We solve for C0,±2C_{0, \pm 2}C0,±2​ by matching terms with the same frequencies. Substitute the ansatz into the reduced EhE^hEh equation:

(∂t−L−μ)(C−2Aˉ2e−2ix+C0AAˉ+C2A2e2ix)=A2e2ix+2AAˉ+Aˉ2e−2ix(\partial_t - L - \mu)(C_{-2}\bar A^2 e^{-2ix} + C_0 A \bar A + C_2 A^2e^{2ix}) = A^2 e^{2ix} + 2A\bar{A} + \bar{A}^2 e^{-2ix}(∂t​−L−μ)(C−2​Aˉ2e−2ix+C0​AAˉ+C2​A2e2ix)=A2e2ix+2AAˉ+Aˉ2e−2ix

Solve for the Mode k=0:

Substitute w0=C0AAˉw_0=C_0 A \bar Aw0​=C0​AAˉ:

  1. LHS wtw_twt​ term: Using A˙≈μA\dot{A}\approx \mu AA˙≈μA, ∂w0∂A=C0Aˉ\frac{\partial w_0}{\partial A} = C_0 \bar{A}∂A∂w0​​=C0​Aˉ, and ∂w0∂Aˉ=C0A\frac{\partial w_0}{\partial \bar{A}} = C_0 A∂Aˉ∂w0​​=C0​A, we have wt≈(μA)(C0Aˉ)+(μAˉ)(C0A)=2μC0AAˉ=2μw0w_t \approx (\mu A)(C_0 \bar{A}) + (\mu \bar{A})(C_0 A) = 2\mu C_0 A \bar{A} = 2\mu w_0wt​≈(μA)(C0​Aˉ)+(μAˉ)(C0​A)=2μC0​AAˉ=2μw0​
  2. LHS LwL wLw term: Lw0=1⋅w0=w0L w_0 = 1 \cdot w_0 = w_0Lw0​=1⋅w0​=w0​
  3. RHS: The constant term in −v2-v^2−v2 is −2AAˉ-2A\bar{A}−2AAˉ.

Assemble the equation for w0w_0w0​:

2μw0−w0−μw0=−2AAˉ2\mu w_0 - w_0 - \mu w_0 = -2A\bar{A}2μw0​−w0​−μw0​=−2AAˉ (μ−1)w0=−2AAˉ(\mu - 1) w_0 = -2A\bar{A}(μ−1)w0​=−2AAˉ w0=21−μAAˉ=21−μ∣A∣2w_0 = \frac{2}{1- \mu} A \bar{A} = \frac{2}{1-\mu} |A|^2w0​=1−μ2​AAˉ=1−μ2​∣A∣2

Solve for the Mode k=2:

Substitute w2=C2A2w_2 = C_2 A^2w2​=C2​A2:

  1. LHS wtw_twt​ term: ∂w2∂A=2C2A,∂w2∂Aˉ=0\frac{\partial w_2}{\partial A} = 2 C_2 A, \quad \frac{\partial w_2}{\partial \bar{A}} = 0∂A∂w2​​=2C2​A,∂Aˉ∂w2​​=0 wt≈(μA)(2C2A)=2μC2A2=2μw2w_t \approx (\mu A)(2 C_2 A) = 2\mu C_2 A^2 = 2\mu w_2wt​≈(μA)(2C2​A)=2μC2​A2=2μw2​
  2. LHS L0wL_0 wL0​w term: Lw2=−3w2L w_2 = -3 w_2Lw2​=−3w2​
  3. RHS: The e2ixe^{2ix}e2ix term in −v2-v^2−v2 is −A2-A^2−A2.

Assemble the equation for w2w_2w2​:

2μw2−(−3w2)−μw2=−A22\mu w_2 - (-3w_2) - \mu w_2 = -A^22μw2​−(−3w2​)−μw2​=−A2 (μ+3)w2=−A2(\mu + 3) w_2 = -A^2(μ+3)w2​=−A2 w2=−1μ+3A2w_2 = -\frac{1}{\mu + 3} A^2w2​=−μ+31​A2

By symmetry (since uuu is real), w−2=wˉ2=−1μ+3Aˉ2w_{-2} = \bar{w}_2 = -\frac{1}{\mu+3}\bar{A}^2w−2​=wˉ2​=−μ+31​Aˉ2.

4. Assemble the Reduced Equation

Return to the equation for A˙\dot{A}A˙:

A˙=μA−⟨v2+2vw+w2,eix⟩\dot{A} = \mu A - \langle v^2 + 2vw + w^2, e^{ix} \rangleA˙=μA−⟨v2+2vw+w2,eix⟩

We analyze the terms inside the bracket that generate the eixe^{ix}eix mode.

  1. v2v^2v2: Contains only 0,±20, \pm 20,±2 modes. No resonance.

  2. w2w^2w2: Although contains resonating terms, it is of order A4A^4A4. Neglect.

  3. 2vw2vw2vw: This is the interaction term.

    2vw=2(Aeix+Aˉe−ix)(w0+w2e2ix+w−2e−2ix)2vw = 2(A e^{ix} + \bar{A} e^{-ix}) \left( w_0 + w_2 e^{2ix} + w_{-2} e^{-2ix} \right)2vw=2(Aeix+Aˉe−ix)(w0​+w2​e2ix+w−2​e−2ix)

    The following terms are proportional to eixe^{ix}eix:

    • 2(Aeix)⋅w0=2Aw0eix2(A e^{ix}) \cdot w_0 = 2 A w_0 e^{ix}2(Aeix)⋅w0​=2Aw0​eix
    • 2(Aˉe−ix)⋅(w2e2ix)=2Aˉw2eix2(\bar{A} e^{-ix}) \cdot (w_2 e^{2ix}) = 2 \bar{A} w_2 e^{ix}2(Aˉe−ix)⋅(w2​e2ix)=2Aˉw2​eix

    Substituting the expressions for w0w_0w0​ and w2w_2w2​ found in the previous step:

    • 2Aw0=2A(21−μAAˉ)=41−μA∣A∣22 A w_0 = 2 A \left( \frac{2}{1-\mu} A \bar{A} \right) = \frac{4}{1-\mu} A |A|^22Aw0​=2A(1−μ2​AAˉ)=1−μ4​A∣A∣2
    • 2Aˉw2=2Aˉ(−1μ+3A2)=−2μ+3A∣A∣22 \bar{A} w_2 = 2 \bar{A} \left( -\frac{1}{\mu + 3} A^2 \right) = -\frac{2}{\mu + 3} A |A|^22Aˉw2​=2Aˉ(−μ+31​A2)=−μ+32​A∣A∣2

Substitute these back into the A˙\dot{A}A˙ equation:

A˙=μA−(41−μ−2μ+3)A∣A∣2+O(∣A∣4)\dot{A} = \mu A - \left( \frac{4}{1-\mu} - \frac{2}{\mu + 3} \right) A |A|^2 + O(|A|^4)A˙=μA−(1−μ4​−μ+32​)A∣A∣2+O(∣A∣4)

If we set μ=0\mu=0μ=0, the equation becomes

A˙=μA−103A∣A∣2+O(∣A∣4)\dot{A} = \mu A - \frac{10}{3} A |A|^2 + O(|A|^4)A˙=μA−310​A∣A∣2+O(∣A∣4)

For even higher order expansion of this reduced equation, one can repeat the procedure (substitution, projection, and matching coefficients) based on this order 3 expansion.

As a final reminder, (A(t),Aˉ(t))(A(t), \bar A(t))(A(t),Aˉ(t)) is the coordinate in the center subspace spanned by e±ixe^{\pm ix}e±ix. So this reduced equation describes the dynamics near the trivial solution (u,μ)=(0,0)(u,\mu)=(0,0)(u,μ)=(0,0). Another note is that www should be thought of as the image of vvv under a smooth1 map hhh, i.e., w=h(v;μ)w = h(v;\mu)w=h(v;μ). By inspecting the Taylor expansion of hhh (suppressing μ\muμ for simplicity):

w=h(v)=h(0)⏟=0+Dh(0)⏟=0+12D2h(0)+…w = h(v) = \underbrace{h(0)}_{=0} + \underbrace{Dh(0)}_{=0} + \frac{1}{2} D^2 h(0) + \ldotsw=h(v)==0h(0)​​+=0Dh(0)​​+21​D2h(0)+…
  • The first term vanishes because the center manifold passes through the point u=0u=0u=0.
  • The second term is zero because the center manifold is tangent to the center subspace at u=0u=0u=0. This is why we can assume www is of order O(∣A∣2)O(|A|^2)O(∣A∣2) in the calculation.

Reference

Local Bifurcations, Center Manifolds, and Normal Forms in Infinite-Dimensional Dynamical Systems by Mariana Haragus and Gérard Iooss.

Footnotes

  1. The regularity of the center manifold is whole another topic. Refer to the book above for more details. ↩
